en.question: Just one of these gives the court jurisdiction.

en.jurisdictionConnectionOneResides: you and your {{ session.divorceWho }} were both last habitually resident and one of you still lives here
en.jurisdictionConnectionPetitioner: your {{ session.divorceWho }}  is habitually resident and has lived here for at least 12 months

en.jurisdictionConnectionOther: The courts of England and Wales have residual jurisdiction, meaning either: no other court in any EU Member State has jurisdiction and either the applicant or the respondent is domiciled in England and Wales; or (for same sex couples only) the applicant or the respondent married each other in England and Wales, no other court in any EU Member State has jurisdiction, and it would be in the interests of justice for the court to assume jurisdiction in this case

habitualResidence.heading: Habitual residence
habitualResidence.summary1: If your lives are mainly based in England or Wales then you're what is legally known as 'habitually resident'.
habitualResidence.summary2: This may include working, owning property, having children in school, and your main family life taking place in England or Wales.
habitualResidence.summary3: The examples above aren't a complete list of what makes up habitual residence, and just because some of them apply to you doesn’t mean you’re habitually resident. If you’re not sure, you should get legal advice.

domicile.heading: Domicile
domicile.summary1: Your domicile is usually the place in which you were born, regard as your permanent home and to which you have the closest ties.
domicile.summary2: However, domicile can be more complex if you or your parents have moved countries in the past.
domicile.summary3Part1: When you're born, you acquire a
domicile.summary3SubText1: the country your father considered his permanent home if your parents were married
domicile.summary3SubText2: the country your mother considered her permanent home if your parents were unmarried, or your father had died
domicile.summary4Part1: If you leave your domicile of origin and settle in another country as an adult, the new country may become your
domicile.summary5: If you're not sure about your domicile you should get legal advice.

residualJurisdiction.heading: Residual Jurisdiction
residualJurisdiction.summary1: Usually, to be eligible for residual jurisdiction, you or your husband/wife must be domiciled in England or Wales, and neither of you must be nationals of, or habitually resident in, another country in the EU (except Denmark).
residualJurisdiction.summary2: However, residual jurisdiction can be more complex. If you’re not sure if this might apply to you, you should seek legal advice.
